questions.text: A patient is brought to casualty and a whole-body CT scan has to be done. This CT scan will include the following except?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) CT Limbs

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In a whole-body CT scan, limbs are not routinely included unless there is specific evidence or suspicion of injury to those areas.
  • ➤ limbs are not routinely included

questions.text: Identify the tip of the pacemaker:
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) RV (Right Ventricle)

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ For a pacemaker, the right ventricle (RV) is always one of the chambers where a lead is placed, especially in dual-lead or single-lead configurations.
  • ➤ the right ventricle (RV)

questions.text: Identify the modality shown here:
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) CT

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The images depict a CT scan , which provides detailed cross-sectional views of the body, often used to evaluate abdominal and thoracic structures.
  • ➤ CT scan

questions.text: In which of the following is MRI better than CT:
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Pancoast tumor

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ MRI is superior to CT in imaging Pancoast tumors due to its ability to better visualize soft tissue involvement, such as the brachial plexus and nearby vascular structures.
  • ➤ MRI
  • ➤ CT
  • ➤ Pancoast tumors

questions.text: What is the imaging modality given below?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) CT enterography

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ CT enterography is the preferred imaging modality for evaluating small bowel pathology, providing detailed cross-sectional images of the intestines with the help of contrast agents.
  • ➤ CT enterography

questions.text: A middle-aged male patient presented with acute onset pain in the right limb. An investigation was performed. What is the name of the investigation?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Ultrasound Doppler

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Ultrasound Doppler is the investigation of choice for assessing blood flow in the limbs, particularly in cases of suspected vascular occlusion or deep vein thrombosis.
  • ➤ Ultrasound Doppler

questions.text: A 25-year-old male presented with a pulsatile supraclavicular neck mass. What is the most appropriate next investigation?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Doppler USG

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ For a pulsatile supraclavicular neck mass , the most appropriate initial investigation is Doppler ultrasound , which is non-invasive and helps to assess the vascularity of the mass, ruling out conditions like aneurysms.
  • ➤ pulsatile supraclavicular neck mass
  • ➤ Doppler ultrasound

questions.text: A 35-year-old smoker male presents with a painful ulcer on the tip of the great toe surrounded by blackish discoloration. The best initial investigation of choice is:
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Doppler USG

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The best initial investigation for evaluating a painful ulcer with blackish discoloration of the toe in a smoker is Doppler Ultrasound (USG) , as it is non-invasive, safe, and effective in assessing peripheral blood flow and vascular compromise.
  • ➤ Doppler Ultrasound (USG)

questions.text: Identify the finding in the given ultrasound image:
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Phrygian cap

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The Phrygian cap is a common and benign anatomical variation of the gallbladder, characterized by a fold in the fundus of the gallbladder, which is clearly depicted in the ultrasound image provided.
  • ➤ Phrygian cap

questions.text: Below is an image of an MRCP scan. Which of the following options is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Choledocholithiasis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Choledocholithiasis , or common bile duct stones, is a common cause of bile duct dilation seen on MRCP scans. This non-invasive imaging technique is particularly useful for detecting biliary obstructions caused by stones.
  • ➤ Choledocholithiasis

questions.text: A 25-year-old male underwent NCCT abdomen for suspected renal calculi. An incidental finding was noted in the liver. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Hydatid cyst

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The hydatid cyst is a parasitic infection commonly found in the liver, presenting as a well-defined cystic lesion on imaging studies such as CT. It is often discovered incidentally during imaging for other conditions.
  • ➤ hydatid cyst

questions.text: Match the following:
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) 1-d, 2-b, 3-a, 4-c

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Football sign : Pneumoperitoneum Rat tail sign : Carcinoma esophagus String sign : CHPS Inverted umbrella sign : Tuberculosis
  • ➤ Football sign : Pneumoperitoneum
  • ➤ Football sign
  • ➤ Rat tail sign : Carcinoma esophagus
  • ➤ Rat tail sign
  • ➤ String sign : CHPS
  • ➤ String sign
  • ➤ Inverted umbrella sign : Tuberculosis
  • ➤ Inverted umbrella sign

questions.text: A 56-year-old male with obstructive jaundice reveals dilated CBD (common bile duct) and intrahepatic biliary radicles (IHBRD) on USG, but no stone was identified. CT confirmed the findings. Which of the following investigations would be most useful to localize the cause?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) MRI

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ When imaging with ultrasound and CT does not reveal the cause of obstructive jaundice , the best next step is MRCP , which provides detailed images of the biliary system and can help localize the cause of the obstruction non-invasively.
  • ➤ obstructive jaundice
  • ➤ MRCP

questions.text: A 35-year-old male presents with severe abdominal pain for the past 2 hours. He recently sustained a radius fracture and has been taking a lot of painkillers. A chest X-ray (CXR) is shown, and the next step needs to be determined.
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Exploratory laparotomy

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The presence of pneumoperitoneum on a chest X-ray, particularly in a patient with a history of NSAID use and acute severe abdominal pain, requires immediate surgical intervention in the form of an exploratory laparotomy to repair the perforation.
  • ➤ pneumoperitoneum
  • ➤ exploratory laparotomy

questions.text: An 8-month-old child, after vaccination, presents to the emergency room with incessant crying and legs drawn up. An X-ray of the abdomen shows signs of free air. The ultrasound (USG) image is provided. What is the next step?
questions.correct_answer: A. Plan for urgent surgical exploration
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Plan for urgent surgical exploration

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In cases of intussusception with evidence of free air (perforation) on imaging, the next step is urgent surgical exploration , as this has become a surgical emergency.
  • ➤ intussusception
  • ➤ free air (perforation)
  • ➤ urgent surgical exploration

questions.text: What is the least useful investigation to confirm the diagnosis of the patient with the following condition as shown in the image below?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) 24-hour pH monitoring

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ For diagnosing achalasia , 24-hour pH monitoring is the least useful investigation, as it is designed to diagnose GERD , not motility disorders.
  • ➤ achalasia
  • ➤ 24-hour pH monitoring
  • ➤ GERD

questions.text: A 45-year-old male presents with sudden onset colicky abdominal pain and vomiting. The supine abdominal X-ray (AXR) is shown here. What is the diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Proximal SBO (Small Bowel Obstruction)

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The X-ray shows features consistent with proximal small bowel obstruction , as indicated by the dilated jejunal loops with prominent valvulae conniventes . This is often associated with sudden onset colicky pain and vomiting due to the obstruction's high location in the small intestine.
  • ➤ proximal small bowel obstruction
  • ➤ valvulae conniventes

questions.text: A 35-year-old male with fever, weight loss since 6 months. Diagnosis based on image?
questions.explanation: Ans. A) GI TB

questions.text: A 30-year-old male patient presented with generalized fatigue, frequent urination, and increased thirst over the past few months. He mentions that he has also been experiencing muscle weakness and occasional abdominal discomfort. His abdominal spine X-ray is shown below. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Hyperparathyroidism

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Hyperparathyroidism is a common cause of hypercalcemia , which can lead to medullary nephrocalcinosis on imaging. The patient's symptoms of fatigue, muscle weakness, and increased thirst, along with the X-ray findings, strongly point to this diagnosis.Bottom of Form
  • ➤ Hyperparathyroidism
  • ➤ hypercalcemia
  • ➤ medullary nephrocalcinosis

questions.text: Double bleb sign seen in early pregnancy is due to?
questions.correct_answer: C. Yolk sac and amniotic sac
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Yolk sac and amniotic sac

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The double bleb sign is a sonographic finding in early pregnancy that represents the yolk sac and amniotic sac , and it helps confirm a normal early intrauterine pregnancy.
  • ➤ double bleb sign
  • ➤ yolk sac
  • ➤ amniotic sac

questions.text: A 35-year-old female presents with a history of nausea and vomiting. She is undergoing IVF treatment. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) OHSS (Ovarian Hyperstimulation Syndrome)

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Ovarian Hyperstimulation Syndrome (OHSS) is a complication of IVF or fertility treatments, and it presents with multiple large ovarian cysts, nausea, vomiting, and abdominal discomfort, as seen in the ultrasound image.
  • ➤ Ovarian Hyperstimulation Syndrome (OHSS)

questions.text: A 30-year-old female presenting with sterile pyuria. Radiograph is shown identify the diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Putty kidney

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Putty kidney is a late-stage complication of renal tuberculosis , presenting with extensive calcification and a shrunken, non-functioning kidney. It is often associated with sterile pyuria due to the chronic nature of the infection.
  • ➤ Putty kidney
  • ➤ renal tuberculosis
  • ➤ sterile pyuria

questions.text: A delayed intravenous urogram of the patient is shown. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Pelviureteric junction obstruction (PUJ obstruction)

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Pelviureteric junction (PUJ) obstruction presents with a dilated renal pelvis and delayed excretion of contrast into the ureter. This condition is typically diagnosed via IVU, showing the characteristic failure of contrast passage from the renal pelvis into the ureter.
  • ➤ Pelviureteric junction (PUJ) obstruction

questions.text: A 37-year-old banker presents with flank pain and a renal lesion is detected on CT. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) AML (Angiomyolipoma)

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Angiomyolipoma (AML) is a benign renal tumor characterized by the presence of fat, blood vessels, and smooth muscle, which appears as a dark, well-defined mass on CT due to the fat content. It is distinguishable from other renal masses such as RCC and renal cysts by its fat signal on imaging.
  • ➤ Angiomyolipoma (AML)

questions.text: A 35-year-old male presents to the trauma centre after a road traffic accident (RTA) with shortness of breath. The supine chest X-ray (CXR) is shown. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Hemothorax

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • The chest X-ray shows a large Hemothorax, which is a common consequence of trauma, particularly in the context of a road traffic accident (RTA). On a supine chest X-ray, hemothorax typically appears as increased opacity due to blood accumulation in the pleural space. In a supine position, blood tends to layer posteriorly and can cause diffuse haziness across the affected hemithorax, which aligns with the image shown.
  • • In this case, hemothorax is the most likely diagnosis due to the trauma background and the radiographic findings of increased density, particularly on one side of the chest, indicating fluid or blood collection.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option B. Pneumothorax: Would show increased radiolucency (darker areas) and possibly a deep sulcus sign, not diffuse opacity.
  • • Option B. Pneumothorax:
  • • Option C. Pulmonary Contusion: Appears as patchy opacities, not the uniform density seen here.
  • • Option C. Pulmonary Contusion:
  • • Option D. Diaphragm Injury: Would show abnormal positioning of abdominal contents, not diffuse chest opacity.
  • • Option D. Diaphragm Injury:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Hemothorax on a supine chest X-ray presents as diffuse opacity in the hemithorax due to blood pooling in the pleural space.

questions.text: Which of the following findings are seen in a high-resolution CT scan of fungal pneumonia?

options.label: D
options.text: Cavitary lesions with surrounding ground glass opacities

questions.correct_answer: D. Cavitary lesions with surrounding ground glass opacities
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Cavitary lesions with surrounding ground glass opacities

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Fungal pneumonia , especially invasive aspergillosis , is characterized by the halo sign (cavitary lesions surrounded by ground-glass opacities), which is a key finding on high-resolution CT (HRCT). Other findings like Kerley lines, hilar lymphadenopathy, and pleural effusions are not typically associated with fungal pneumonia.
  • ➤ Fungal pneumonia
  • ➤ invasive aspergillosis
  • ➤ halo sign

questions.text: Which of the following is true regarding CORADS-COVID-19 Reporting and Data System:

options.label: C
options.text: Pleural thickening is typical of COVID-19

options.label: D
options.text: Lobar consolidation is typical of COVID-19

questions.correct_answer: B. CORADS-5 is typical of COVID-19
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) CORADS-5 is typical of COVID-19

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ CORADS-5 is highly typical of COVID-19 and involves bilateral ground-glass opacities on CT, which are hallmarks of the infection. The system ranges from incomplete or technically inadequate scans (CORADS-0) to confirmed COVID-19 (CORADS-6).
  • ➤ CORADS-5

questions.text: A 45-year-old male presents to the trauma centre post road traffic accident (RTA). He is conscious, talking and vitals are stable. The chest X-ray (CXR) is shown. Which of the following procedures is contraindicated?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) ICD tube drainage

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In cases of diaphragmatic rupture with herniation of abdominal contents into the thoracic cavity, placing an ICD (intercostal drainage tube) is contraindicated because it can lead to perforation of herniated organs like the stomach or bowel.
  • ➤ diaphragmatic rupture
  • ➤ ICD (intercostal drainage tube)

questions.text: A 35-year-old female presents with fever, expectoration, and difficulty breathing. An HRCT of the chest was performed and is shown. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Consolidation with air bronchogram

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Consolidation with air bronchogram is a typical finding in pneumonia , where alveoli are filled with exudate or fluid, while the air-filled bronchi remain visible. The presence of fever, cough, and difficulty breathing further supports the diagnosis of pneumonia.
  • ➤ Consolidation with air bronchogram
  • ➤ pneumonia

questions.text: A 6-year-old child presents with hypertension. On examination, lower limb pulsation was feeble, and upper limb pulses were normal. On chest X-ray, notching of the ribs was noted. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Coarctation of Aorta

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Coarctation of the aorta should be suspected in children presenting with hypertension, discrepancies between upper and lower limb pulses, and rib notching on chest X-ray due to collateral circulation.
  • ➤ Coarctation of the aorta

questions.text: Identify the true statement based on the chest X-ray shown.

options.label: A
options.text: Left heart border silhouette sign negative

options.label: D
options.text: Location cannot be commented without CT

questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Location in Lingula

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The silhouette sign is an important diagnostic tool on chest X-rays. If the left heart border is obscured, the pathology is likely in the lingula , which is part of the left upper lobe and adjacent to the heart.
  • ➤ silhouette sign
  • ➤ left heart border
  • ➤ lingula

questions.text: A 34-year-old woman presents to the emergency department after a road traffic accident with a Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS) score of 3. She was intubated and sent for a non-contrast CT (NCCT), which was found to be normal. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) DAI (Diffuse Axonal Injury)

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Diffuse Axonal Injury (DAI) should be suspected in patients with severe trauma and a normal NCCT. MRI is the preferred imaging modality for detecting DAI, as it can reveal the microscopic axonal injuries that are not visible on CT.
  • ➤ Diffuse Axonal Injury (DAI)
  • ➤ MRI

questions.text: Which of the following is most likely to be seen due to rupture of a saccular aneurysm in the brain?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Subarachnoid Haemorrhage

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Subarachnoid hemorrhage (SAH) is the most likely consequence of a ruptured saccular aneurysm in the brain, presenting with sudden severe headache and detectable on NCCT.
  • ➤ Subarachnoid hemorrhage (SAH)
  • ➤ ruptured saccular aneurysm

questions.text: A 10-year-old boy presented with a seizure and then fell unconscious. Imaging was done, and the result is shown here. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) NCC (Neurocysticercosis)

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Neurocysticercosis (NCC) is the most likely diagnosis in a child with seizures and a ring-enhancing lesion on imaging, especially in regions where Taenia solium is endemic. This parasitic infection is the leading cause of acquired epilepsy in children and young adults.
  • ➤ Neurocysticercosis (NCC)

questions.text: Identify the technique shown in the image below.
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Myelography

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Myelography is a technique used to image the spinal cord and nerve roots using contrast material, allowing for enhanced visualization of spinal abnormalities.
  • ➤ Myelography

questions.text: A 2-month-old infant is brought to the OPD with a parietal swelling present since birth. An X-ray was ordered and is shown below. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Cephalhematoma

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Cephalhematoma is a subperiosteal hemorrhage confined by suture lines, which can present as a localized swelling with calcification on imaging, particularly after a few weeks or months. It is commonly associated with birth trauma and can persist for an extended period as it heals.
  • ➤ Cephalhematoma

questions.text: Identify the marked structure in the image.
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Internal capsule

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The internal capsule is a white matter pathway located between the putamen and thalamus. It is an essential structure for transmitting motor and sensory information between the cerebral cortex and the spinal cord. The marked structure in the image is the internal capsule .
  • ➤ internal capsule
  • ➤ internal capsule

questions.text: A 35-year-old female presents with a thunderclap headache. Based on the image provided, what is the likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) SAH (Subarachnoid Hemorrhage)

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ A subarachnoid hemorrhage (SAH) is most commonly caused by the rupture of an aneurysm and presents with a thunderclap headache . On CT, it appears as hyperdensity in the subarachnoid space , particularly in the basal cisterns . This imaging finding, along with the clinical presentation, strongly suggests SAH.
  • ➤ subarachnoid hemorrhage (SAH)
  • ➤ thunderclap headache
  • ➤ hyperdensity in the subarachnoid space
  • ➤ basal cisterns

questions.text: A 56-year-old male presents with sudden onset right hemiplegia. Based on the image provided, what is the likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Hypertensive hemorrhage

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ A hypertensive hemorrhage commonly occurs in the basal ganglia and is often associated with sudden neurological deficits, such as hemiplegia . CT scans show hyperdense areas corresponding to the hemorrhage, and hypertension is a key risk factor.
  • ➤ hypertensive hemorrhage
  • ➤ basal ganglia
  • ➤ hemiplegia

questions.text: What is the likely diagnosis based on the image?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Lacunar stroke

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Lacunar strokes are small, well-defined areas of infarction that typically affect deep brain structures like the basal ganglia and are commonly associated with hypertension . They present as small hypodense areas on CT scans.
  • ➤ Lacunar strokes
  • ➤ basal ganglia
  • ➤ hypertension

questions.text: A patient presents to the emergency department with chronic ear discharge, headache, and ear pain. CT revealed the following findings. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Temporal abscess

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ A temporal lobe abscess is a common complication of chronic otitis media , and it typically presents as a ring-enhancing lesion on CT imaging. The patient's history of chronic ear discharge and the location of the lesion point to this diagnosis.
  • ➤ temporal lobe abscess
  • ➤ chronic otitis media
  • ➤ ring-enhancing lesion

questions.text: A 10-year-old child presents to the emergency with sudden onset of vision loss in the bilateral temporal fields. NCCT head was done. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Craniopharyngioma

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ A craniopharyngioma is a common benign tumor in children that often presents with bitemporal hemianopia due to compression of the optic chiasm. The presence of calcification in the suprasellar region on imaging is a key diagnostic feature.
  • ➤ craniopharyngioma
  • ➤ bitemporal hemianopia
  • ➤ calcification
  • ➤ suprasellar region

questions.text: A 26-year-old male presents with backache, morning stiffness, and reddening of the eyes. The X-ray of the patient is shown below. Identify the diagnosis.
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Ankylosing spondylitis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Ankylosing spondylitis is characterized by fusion of the spine (bamboo spine) and typically presents with chronic back pain , morning stiffness , and other systemic symptoms like anterior uveitis . The X-ray findings in conjunction with the clinical presentation are diagnostic of this condition.
  • ➤ Ankylosing spondylitis
  • ➤ fusion of the spine
  • ➤ chronic back pain
  • ➤ morning stiffness
  • ➤ anterior uveitis

questions.text: A 35-year-old male presented with pain and swelling around the wrist joint. There is no history of injury. The X-ray is shown below. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Giant cell tumor

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ A giant cell tumor (GCT) is a benign, expansile lesion commonly seen in the epiphysis of long bones near joints. The classic soap bubble appearance on X-ray and the absence of a history of injury help to differentiate it from other conditions.
  • ➤ giant cell tumor (GCT)
  • ➤ epiphysis
  • ➤ soap bubble appearance

questions.text: A patient presents with persistent back pain and a past history of pulmonary TB. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Psoas abscess

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ A psoas abscess is a common complication of spinal tuberculosis (Pott's disease), and it presents with back pain and constitutional symptoms like fever. A history of TB and persistent back pain should raise suspicion for this condition.
  • ➤ psoas abscess
  • ➤ spinal tuberculosis
  • ➤ back pain

questions.text: Identify the diagnosis based on the provided X-ray.
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Multiple enchondromas

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Multiple enchondromas (Ollier's disease) present as multiple lytic lesions that expand and deform the bones, particularly in the hands. These benign cartilage tumors occur in the medullary cavity and can cause significant skeletal deformities.
  • ➤ Multiple enchondromas

questions.text: All of the following are useful in osteoporosis: DEXA Quantitative CT Bone scan Chemical analysis
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) 1, 2, 4

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ DEXA and Quantitative CT are direct tools for assessing bone density, while chemical analysis aids in understanding the metabolic aspects of bone health. Bone scans are not used for diagnosing osteoporosis.
  • ➤ DEXA
  • ➤ Quantitative CT
  • ➤ chemical analysis

questions.text: A 40-year-old woman presented with confusion, constipation, and persistent low mood. ALP was elevated, and she was diagnosed with primary hyperparathyroidism. Which of the following is the imaging of choice?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Sestamibi scan

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In primary hyperparathyroidism , the Sestamibi scan is the imaging modality of choice to localize parathyroid adenomas or hyperplasia, enabling precise surgical intervention.
  • ➤ primary hyperparathyroidism
  • ➤ Sestamibi scan
  • ➤ parathyroid adenomas

questions.text: Which is the most radiosensitive bone tumor?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Ewing sarcoma

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Ewing sarcoma is the most radiosensitive bone tumor, often treated with a combination of surgery, radiation, and chemotherapy for optimal outcomes.
  • ➤ Ewing sarcoma

questions.text: A woman diagnosed with endometrial carcinoma is undergoing radiotherapy. Choose the correct statement:

options.label: A
options.text: Intensity is inversely proportional to the square of the distance from the source

options.label: B
options.text: Small blood vessels are most radioresistant

options.label: C
options.text: Rapidly proliferating cells are most radioresistant

options.label: D
options.text: Small intestinal mucosa is most radio resistant

questions.correct_answer: A. Intensity is inversely proportional to the square of the distance from the source
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Intensity is inversely proportional to the square of the distance from the source

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The correct statement is that the intensity of radiation follows the inverse square law , meaning it decreases significantly as the distance from the source increases. Rapidly proliferating cells and tissues like the intestinal mucosa are among the most radiosensitive.
  • ➤ intensity of radiation
  • ➤ inverse square law
  • ➤ Rapidly proliferating cells
  • ➤ intestinal mucosa
